job_title: Director, Content Creation in Sioux Falls, SD
pros:
I have experience with both non-profit and for-profit communications agencies. I have found my time with the Good Samaritan Society to be positive and rewarding. My co-workers and superiors continue to encourage my career growth, and my Christian faith. I have been promoted twice in the almost nine years I've worked here. I also have created professional friendships with co-workers across the United States since we have 240 locations in 24 states.

The best thing I can say about the Good Samaritan Society is that I also am a client. My mother has a wonderful relationship with the visiting nurses who work for one of our local agencies. They are professional and caring. I couldn't have the life that I have if they weren't here to help me care for my mother as she ages in her own home.
cons: I'm well aware of the negative feelings that some of my co-workers have for the national headquarters where I work. What I wish is that we had more time to connect across the miles. I do as many long-distance training and support phone calls as I can, but that's not enough. Respect and trust are key in our relationships between headquarters and our local centers.

pros: The focus is on the residents of the facility. I would put a loved one there if the need arose, as have many of my co-workers. I think that says alot. I wouldn't want to work somewhere that I wouldn't trust my own mother to be taken care of. The pay rate is fair. We are unionized.
cons: I don't think we get enough praise for the good job we do. I also think our benefit package leaves something to be desired. Who can afford to pay $1000 out of their pocket every year and then 30% after that? Not the average single parent family. I also believe that management forgets that the reason that our residents are so well taken care of is the front line of the nusing facility and when you don't try to make your employees happy or at least work together then the quality of our work seems to diminish because of the discontent.

pros: Other than the residents, there is nothing good I can say about working here. Love the residents.  They deserve better. They are why I have stayed as long as I have but unfortunately it is time to go.
cons: The village is so poorly run by upper management.  Sanford Health came in at the first of the year and those of us that care about the residents hoped they would see that management is the problem.  Instead management continues to get away with their bad behavior so almost all of the good employees are gone and I'm running out the door with them.  Do not work for this company in any of the Florida locations especially Kissimmee. They don't care about the employees at all and worse they don't care about the residents.  They have their own agenda and it has nothing to do with the village.

review_title: Certified Nursing Assistant in Skilled Nursing Facility.
job_title: CNA in Moscow, ID
pros: The nurses, CNAs, and management personally care about the residents and do their best to put residents first. The management also makes sure to listen to the CNAs and often took steps to make everyone's job easier.
cons:
- Frequently understaffed given the number of residents to care for. Other CNAs regularly did not show up for their shifts. 
- The nurses are hit or miss: some of them care about teamwork and helping CNAs, others will give CNAs as much extra work as they can.
- Pay raises are nominal and not based on performance; I regularly received compliments on my work ethic from nurses and management yet only received a $0.34 raise after working for 1.5 years(most CNAs stay less than 1 year).

review_title: A caring work enviornment with a lot of beurocracy
job_title: in Sioux Falls, SD
pros:
(I am a former National Campus employee)
The work environment is filled with caring people in an environment that is open to discussing faith and worshiping together. The best part of working at the Society, for me, was the organization's mission. Your work helps impact the care of older adults and their families who are trying to balance and navigate the changing health of their loved one.
cons: There is a lot of red tape. Employees aren't empowered to make decisions. Instead, a lot of upper management gets involved in making a lot of big and small decisions that make the whole organization move slowly. The company was also experiencing a financial crunch when I was there and it was very stressful. We were already doing more with less, but then it became do more with even less.

review_title: National Campus - a hard place to work
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Sioux Falls, SD
pros: the benefits were pretty good as were the hours.
cons:
The people. I met a few really great people that I miss working with but, in general, the people at NC were awful. Here's a few examples: 

1.  It was a routine experience to get abuse from coworkers both at NC and from the centers, especially from people who were in higher management positions or had been there for years and were well connected. When I would report this to my supervisors, I was told that I had to accept it because that's just the way the person was even though I would get written up if I treated someone that way. 
2. favoritism: its very obvious. I've watched unqualified people get promoted up simply because of who they knew only to have their job requirements restructured down to fit their ability.

job_title: in Estherville, IA
pros: I love working with the residents and feeling as though I make a positive difference in their daily lives.  My job is satisfying in a way that cannot be found in many other jobs.  Helping others is very rewarding.
cons: Upper management is very closeminded and doesn't listen to the ideas and opinions of the 'little people'.  There is a very strong impression that employees are to keep their mouths closed and do and they say without questions.  They have created a work enviornment that is highly stressful and disruptive to both residents and workers.

review_title: Like Family; Low Pay and Fewer Responsibilities
job_title: Programmer in Sioux Falls, SD
pros: Good-Sam shows respect towards most of their employees.  It is a casual place to work and great for those who are financially well off.  Good-Sam values their employees' time and very rarely requires overtime.
cons: Pay raises are linked to an index published around June of the preceding year.  Pay raises are the same for all employees and are not linked in any way to job performance unless one has been written up (which seems rare).  Good-Sam has a communication problem and employees will find out the facts from a local newspaper before the company mentions anything, if at all.

review_title: Actions Do Not Reflect Their Mission Statement
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Greeley, CO
pros:
* Helping residents and their families
* Decent work/life balance
* PTO accrual sufficient
cons:
* Directors are unprofessional, talk down to residents and employees
* Negative place to work, no support from upper management
* Unable to serve our community, turning too many people away and over priced for condition of facility
* Zero raises for over 5 years now, not even cost of living increases
* No opportunities for growth or to learn something new

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Kissimmee, FL
pros: The Administration staff was supportive to staff needs and supported me in decisions that had to be made in our office.
cons: Turnaround  with Directors was very high, couldn't keep a director in their position what seemed like more than one year if even that. Very high stress level of work, their is a definite need for an Assistant Director which is what I was essentially doing but without the title or the pay. I ran that Dept for years without a Director and things were fine, then another would come in and mess things up again.

job_title: in Sioux Falls, SD
pros: It used to be a faith based organization.
cons: Over the last several years there has been a culture shift in this organization. It used to be a faith based organization. However,  the organization is becoming increasingly secular (to appeal to a larger market).  The last several years the company has posted operating losses ranging from 25-30 million a year. A 30 million dollar building was built at National Campus only to lay off 100 employees. Reports are internally that the building cost closer to 46 million. Poor leadership from Dave Horazdovsky and Bergan Peterson have destroyed this company. Do not work for this company. They do not make a profit and there is no room for growth. Benefits have declined over the years due to lack of revenue. Now pay will be tied to operating performance. You will not reach the mid-point in your position if the organization continues to perform poorly.  No opportunity. GSS relies heavily on Medicaid and Medicare - with the cuts coming to these two payers it is unlikely this company will be able to survive.

job_title: CNA in Waterville, MN
pros: I love the people I work for to help and some of the people I work with. They give you the experience you need and they will even put you through the CNA classes.
cons: The people who have been there for a long time walk around the place like they own it and don't feel they have help you or anyone for that matter. They take extra time on their breaks when there's a lot going on and then sit and chart for another however long after that ungodly long break. Then when you bring it up to management nothing happens. There is no teamwork. When you need a shift covered good luck getting anyone to help you out! There's a lot of gossip at this place too so don't make one wrong move or you will be the new subject of discussion.

job_title: R N Staff Nurse in Davenport, IA
pros: In Christ's Love, Everyone is Someone. Initially, good staffing ratios compared to other facilities. Recent upgrades included full kitchen & dining areas in each hall, for the convenience of residents and families. New hospice 2 room suites for residents and families.
cons: Lower and lower staffing reflecting the "new reality", meaning less nurse face time spent with residents, and more time in charting as more tasks are delegated to floor nurses. Frustrating, less than user friendly EMR systems, clearly designed without any nurse consultation, making an already hard job, much more difficult. Over my years there, it became less of a friendly nursing home, to almost a hospital-like environment. More acutely ill residents, with more challenging co-morbidities accepted without increasing or reorganizing already stretched staff.

job_title: Dining Room Attendant in Greeley, CO
pros: Nice because you get lots of interaction with residents, and the nurses can be great.
cons: The management had a total lack of communication, and only a couple managers were pleasant to be around (most were grumpy and scolded employees like children). The other servers were all high schoolers with a complete disregard for manners or rules.

job_title: Charge Nurse Licensed Practical Nurse in Kearney, NE
pros: The pay is good. If you like to work independently this is your job. No team work here. You are definitely on your own.
cons: No real orientation. They call it orientation but they just put you on the floor and no one wants to train you. Everyone will complain that you are not trained, but no one will do anything about it. When your 30 days of orientation are over they don't ask if your ready or have any questions they just put you on the schedule and out on the floor.

job_title: Charge Nurse Licensed Practical Nurse in Luverne, MN
pros: Generally speaking this is a good organization to work for. Worked first as a CNA, then as an LPN in one of the smaller towns. Fairly good pay and benefits, offer free training for CEU's. It does depend however, on where you are working.
cons: ALWAYS understaffed! Nurses often end up working the floor due to being short on CNA's. Poor direction from management, during weekly meetings they emphasize how you should "take charge" of your CNA's/wings to make sure things are being done correctly as the resident level of care ultimately reflects back on you. However, when you try to do that, and call out the few CNA's who aren't doing their job, causing the others to be overworked, and resident care to be lax, then you get called out for upsetting the CNA's or being too "hard" on them.

review_title: Anonymous at Sioux Falls National Campus
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Sioux Falls, SD
pros: There are some incredibly kind, bright and capable people who worked, and still work, for Good Sam.
cons: Opacity of leadership has created a growing divide between those steering the organization and those they depend on to accomplish their vision.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Sioux Falls, SD
pros: Very rewarding to see how dedicated our employees are in their desire to provided personalized care and services to seniors.   Our managers and employees work together and have a Can-Do attitude even when the challenges are great, and there isn't enough time in a day to get everything accomplished.    So rewarding to see resident's smiles, and the connections to the community.
cons: We are faced with obstacles in reimbursement and cultural attitudes of people in our communities that "nursing homes" are not the desired place of care.  We need more employees and community members and legislators to support our efforts as we provide our mission focused services.

job_title: Administrator in Minneapolis, MN
pros: At first the mission statement appealed to me.
cons:
1. The CEO is making over 3/4 of a million dollars a year at a time they are cutting over 100 staff members and building a 30 million corporate office and minimally staffing their nursing homes
2. I visited The Eugene, Oregon nursing home......It really reflects the downward trend this organization has been going......Senior management has lost focus over the years and have misplaced values compared to it's beginnings
3. The governing board is too close to the CEO to perform objective reviews. I would invite members of the governing board to visit the Eugene Good Samaritan Nursing home to determine for themselves if corporate policies need to be revised..

job_title: LVN in El Paso, TX
pros: Pay is great, they give opportunities to new nurses.
cons: Favoritism, everyone's nice at first then after a while everyone turns. Nurse to patient ratio is not safe. 3-4 admissions with no help plus your 3 hallways. Everything has to be done in your 8hr shift.  When help is needed no other nurse is to be found.

review_title: More Concerned with BUDGET than Quality of Care/Life
job_title: Dietary Aide in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Always have the option of shifts to pick up. Decent pay. Ability to cross train in departments. Benefits are reasonable.
cons: Always understaffed, lack of cooperation from coworkers, unrealistic expectations of management, management more concerned with budget rather than quality of care, management is not knowledgeable of what is occurring in own departments. The resident care is severely lacking. The number of "good, caring" nurses and nursing assistants can NOT make up for the slack that the "poor" nurses and nursing assistants leave behind. Management

review_title: Good nursing home to work at
job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant in Lenexa, KS

I have requested a schedule change many times because I am in school and I always get the new schedule I need. There are often employee appreciation days where pizza or sandwiches are provided for every shift. They clearly want their staff to be happy.
cons: Often short-staffed, but that goes along with pretty much any nursing home. Sometimes bad aides are not held accountable for poor care or they have not been trained well enough to know how to provide good care.

job_title: CNA in Waconia, MN

review_title: There is so much love and grace working with our elders in this mutually supportive environment.
job_title: in Albuquerque, NM
pros: It's the frst job I've had (working for decades) where I really felt permission to stop and listen to someone. That's part of your job here. I appreciate that. The residents come first. It is very rewarding to acknowledge and include people.
cons: If I don't watch out, I can stay overtime. Sometimes, it's hard to walk away from unfinished tasks until the next day. But i'm getting better at that balance.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Beatrice, NE

cons: Since we are a non-profit 501(C)3 we rely on the kindness of others for donations to our projects.  We have amazing staff and community members who support our extra activities, but sometimes it takes longer then what people have patience for to come to fruition.

review_title: Horrible, the DON along with other management only cares for themselves and making money-not the residents.

MANAGEMENT!

job_title: in Lakota, ND

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Arlington, MN

review_title: Always a struggle to get employees

job_title: Nicole Mikulics in Fort Collins, CO

job_title: Resource Director in Larimore, ND

review_title: Rewarding experience with great people, but terrible pay

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Colorado Springs, CO

Residents feel as if or when they complain they will be ignored or have no one to complain too. Residents are being told to move if they don’t like it when they do complain. Residents are now treated as a number. Staff that stood for the Good Samaritan Way, are bullied or eliminated by management. Staff and residents are now living in fear. Residents are now receiving poor treatment and neglect. The Christ centered atmosphere is gone.

job_title: Nursing Assistant in Lovington, NM

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant in Lovington, NM
pros: The co-workers where very nice and helpful whenever you needed their help. The pay is really good. From time to time, fun activities take place for the residents and the staff.

job_title: RN Charge in Moscow, ID
pros: The residents were great, and most of the stsff was also!
cons: A new administrator turned it into a war zon ,e. For months there was no DNS, so the nurse managers took turns doing ot! They did not communicate with each other, one day something you were doing was correct,  then the next day it was wrong, you never knew who to talk to if there was a  problem from day to day!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Estherville, IA
pros: There a few who still cares.
cons:
It is a long one:

This place has many major issues. The facility here in Estherville are in such an utter disarray, no real leadership at all. Scheduling and staffing are not done by one department. Administrative jobs are so spread out, there is no streamlining of functions going on. They need real leadership here.
I saw no long-term goals while I was there. There is very little planning or directions going on, workers barely knowing what’s going to happen the next day, except the Upper Management’s favorites, they know what in the plans for the week. To be fair, there are a couple of good workers in there, but they are doing their best with what little tools they are given. They need more good workers and get rid of the bad ones. 
The Administrative Support Staff workers are poorly trained. They have favorites workers too, so the enforcement of rules is not consistent, they will not write them up but will write others up for the same offenses. They are not very honest, they do not keep their promises, they’re cut hours of some workers and giving them to others. They are selective in accommodating a worker with disabilities and not others. They are not recruiting, and screening, interviewing applicants properly. 
Confidentiality is a nil there, paperwork lays around for others to see and read. For example: a coworker filled some paperwork out for time off for medical reasons. Someone read it and tell someone else. Another example: when a co-worker had an urgent private matter that needed to be attend to. She had only told the Upper Management in confidence and requested time off. Well, the Upper Management talked about the private matter and the co-worker came back and was dismayed to find her private matter made the gossip mill among the staff and residences. When she complained, she was taken aside and scolded by another Upper Management staff, so she quit. Also, the security cameras? Anyone could view the videos then gossiped about what they viewed. Yes, it had happened many times while I was there. Only the Upper Management should be allowed to see the videos. No confidentiality at all, there.
A new person gets little training. Many of the workers who been there for years are behaving like a pack and gang-up on a new person. It is hostile environment, and it is growing worse at time goes by.  Some new staff and residents are being mistreated. Good workers come then quickly leaves when they realize how bad it is there. I had complained about a volatile action that was taken against me from a co-worker. I could have been injured.  She was spoke to about it. Since she was one of their favorites, so she was still there, and I moved to another department.
There are far too many young adults, no mature person on the evening shifts. They want to finish their work quickly and as result incomplete with the residents, they rush through their duties, just so they could sit down, and talk. They don’t handle the expensive equipment correctly, and they slammed furniture around. The good nurses had tried telling them to do better work, but they don’t listen to them and the Upper Management don’t back them up. If they write them up, the Upper Management will give the name of who wrote up and the nurses suffer retaliations from the worker and their friends.  Good workers who stays, they moved to other shifts to get away from them. The residents suffer for it. The numbers of skin tears, infections, and depressions are growing. When they are put to bed at 7:30pm and they are wide awake at 2am. When there is one CNA on staff for 30 some residents at night and it is overwhelming to care for them when they want one on one attention. 
They’re had been short of staff on nights and they are overwork since January 2018 and the few staff left are pushed to give adequate cares the residents required. They call you day and night to work. Many concerns are voiced but are not addressed, except the major ones, that would get state attention are quickly handled. 
There is an imbalance of support between shifts. One is invisible, least of thought of, while the other is first thought of when there extra money in the budget.

review_title: a wonderful place to be employed :)

review_title: Low pay, no raises, unpaid hours worked on holidays
job_title: Housekeeper in Brainerd, MN
pros: Relationships with residents and some staff
cons: They don't do raises ever, not even yearly cost of living raises. I just learned that even though they do pay holiday pay when you work one, they average it out to only pay you 5 out of 7 hour shift so that you still make the same amount of money you would on a normal day. Constantly overworked. My knees are going bad after 1 year of working here. Disrespect from nurses and aides, and impossible deadlines for apartment turnovers from upper management. You are expected to clean the apartment cielings, walls, floors, counters, toilet, sinks, shower, light sqotches, oven, fridge, outlets, baseboards, doors, door frames, under stove and fridge, closets and cupboards including all shelves and inside and out, you must climb the counters to clean the tops of cupboards. And all this is expected to be done in less than 6 hours and at your normal pay rate. They hide behind being "non profit" as to why they can't pay more or improve working conditions. On a normal day I clean 12 apartments in 7 hours with 2 15 min breaks and no 1/2hr lunch. After the apartments are done in which you can spend no more than 35 mins per apartment, you must vacuum the hallway, dust all light foxtures, disinfect handrails, and wash the walls. It is too.much for one person And we are constantly understaffed. Because no one wants to do hard physical labor for $11 an hour while enduring disrespect from all sides. And my job is easy compared to the care center housekeepers. They must clean up to 40 rooms per day in the same 7 hour shift. They are smaller and 2 rooms share a bathroom but it is obvious why they can't get anyone new to work there. I will be looking for new employment very soon because i am absolutely disgusted by their treatment of most of their staff. They pay lip service about how were all needed but it's all fake. Nothing ever changes and it never will.
